docs.lead_paragraph: -SCHOOL friend was ''allergic'' to the cold. She was embarrassed to go to school on cold, windy days because her face would be covered with raised, red, itchy blotches, commonly called hives, by the time she had walked the four blocks from her home. Another friend developed a form of hives wherever his skin was rubbed. The red, raised marks would take the shape of the irritating object: a line if scratched by a fingernail, a band if rubbed by a tight waistband, an itchy circle under his wristwatch.

docs.lead_paragraph: -fund money manager, recently sold his company's position in Stride Rite Shoes, a maker of baby shoes, for two-and-a-half times the purchase price. Kinder-Care and La Petite Academies, two day-care center companies, are also realizing handsome gains in his portfolio. When asked why his investment picks cater to the preschool crowd, Mr. McKay answers simply, ''demographics.'' Because women born during the post-World War II baby boom are now having children, the swelling numbers of preschoolers translate into greater demand for child care products and services, a trend that savvy investors like Mr. McKay can prosper from. Demography is, in its broadest sense, the statistical study of population trends. While the United States Census Bureau has been putting together the data for decades, advanced computer technology and the greater use of market research have made demographics a more useful and sophisticated forecasting tool. Business planners and investors are increasingly scrutinizing income, occupation, education and lifestyle characteristics of targeted age groups to find better ways to position products and services, as well as personal investments, in coming years.
